articles.headline: Arizona Border Quiets After Gains in Security
articles.snippet: As Congress debates an overhaul of immigration laws, border officials in Arizona say that they have already made many enforcement advances that lawmakers seek.
articles.abstract: As Congress debates an overhaul of immigration laws, border officials in Arizona say that they have already made many enforcement advances that lawmakers seek.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOGALES, Ariz. — Flying low along the Mexican line in a Black Hawk helicopter, the United States Border Patrol officer saw surveillance towers rising above the cactus. He saw his agents’ white and green trucks moving among the mesquite, scouting for illegal crossers.

articles.headline: Looking for a Lesson in Google’s Perks
articles.snippet: Whatever might be said of Yahoo’s workplace, it’s a long way from Google’s, whose various offices reflect the company’s overarching philosophy to create a happy and productive environment.
articles.abstract: Whatever might be said of Yahoo’s workplace, it’s a long way from Google’s, whose various offices reflect the company’s overarching philosophy to create a happy and productive environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, ordered employees working from home to show up at the office for work, there was speculation that she was emulating Google, her previous employer.

articles.headline: SAC Capital to Pay $616 Million in Insider Trading Cases
articles.snippet: Two affiliates of the giant hedge fund have settled insider trading cases with the S.E.C., for $616 million, in what the agency said was the biggest ever settlement for such cases.
articles.abstract: Two affiliates of the giant hedge fund have settled insider trading cases with the S.E.C., for $616 million, in what the agency said was the biggest ever settlement for such cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: 10:58 p.m. | Updated

articles.headline: Is the Seller to Blame?
articles.snippet: After a soldier died, his parents took aim at a dietary supplement — and the retail chain GNC, where he bought it.
articles.abstract: After a soldier died, his parents took aim at a dietary supplement — and the retail chain GNC, where he bought it.
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERY morning as she gets dressed for her accounting job, Leanne Sparling hangs her son’s military dog tags and a photograph of him in uniform around her neck. She wears the tags on the outside of her clothes, hoping to prompt strangers to ask about him. “When I do tell them what happened,” she says, “they are in total disbelief.”
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: U.S. Is Bolstering Missile Defense to Deter North Korea
articles.snippet: The Pentagon will deploy more missile interceptors on the Pacific Coast to counter the growing reach of North Korea’s weapons, a decision accelerated by Pyongyang’s recent belligerence.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon will deploy more missile interceptors on the Pacific Coast to counter the growing reach of North Korea’s weapons, a decision accelerated by Pyongyang’s recent belligerence.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon will spend $1 billion to deploy additional ballistic missile interceptors along the Pacific Coast to counter the growing reach of North Korea’s weapons, a decision accelerated by Pyongyang’s recent belligerence and indications that Kim Jong-un, the North Korean leader, is resisting China’s efforts to restrain him.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker, David E. Sanger and Martin Fackler

articles.headline: New Laws Take Guesswork Out of Investment Tax Liability
articles.snippet: Investors will need to keep a sharp eye on their cost basis statements from brokers and banks, lest they invite an I.R.S. inquiry.
articles.abstract: Investors will need to keep a sharp eye on their cost basis statements from brokers and banks, lest they invite an I.R.S. inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until recently, the tax man rarely held you accountable for how much you profited — or lost — when you sold stocks or mutual funds.

articles.headline: Ford Chief Benefits From Auto Comeback
articles.snippet: The pay levels at Ford and General Motors far exceed what the companies were paying their executives a few years ago, when the automakers were losing billions of dollars.
articles.abstract: The pay levels at Ford and General Motors far exceed what the companies were paying their executives a few years ago, when the automakers were losing billions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: The turnaround of the American auto industry is paying off for senior management, particularly at the Ford Motor Company, even with a 29 percent reduction in compensation for its chief executive.

articles.headline: Ethanol Surplus May Lift Gas Prices
articles.snippet: To meet federal mandates, refiners trade ethanol credits, whose prices have jumped nearly tenfold since January, adding to costs at the pump, experts say.
articles.abstract: To meet federal mandates, refiners trade ethanol credits, whose prices have jumped nearly tenfold since January, adding to costs at the pump, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A glut of ethanol in the gasoline supply is threatening to push up prices at the pump and may have exacerbated the growing cost gap between regular gasoline and premium, some oil experts say.

articles.headline: Withering Questions at Senate Hearing on JPMorgan Loss
articles.snippet: Lawmakers took aim at JPMorgan Chase for misleading investors and regulators about a disastrous bet, building off a scathing 300-page Congressional report released on Thursday.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers took aim at JPMorgan Chase for misleading investors and regulators about a disastrous bet, building off a scathing 300-page Congressional report released on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top JPMorgan Chase executive struggled to defend his actions on Friday as lawmakers scrutinized the bank’s multibillion-dollar trading loss.

articles.headline: Worldly at 35, and Shaping Obama’s Voice
articles.snippet: Benjamin J. Rhodes is a 35-year-old deputy national security adviser with a soft voice, strong opinions and a reputation as the man who channels President Obama on foreign policy.
articles.abstract: Benjamin J. Rhodes is a 35-year-old deputy national security adviser with a soft voice, strong opinions and a reputation as the man who channels President Obama on foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama prepares to visit Israel next week, he is turning, as he often does, to Benjamin J. Rhodes, a 35-year-old deputy national security adviser with a soft voice, strong opinions and a reputation around the White House as the man who channels Mr. Obama on foreign policy.

articles.headline: Boom Over, St. Patrick’s Isle Is Slithering Again
articles.snippet: During the Celtic Tiger boom, snakes became a popular pet among the Irish nouveau riche. But after the bubble burst, many owners abandoned the pets they could no longer afford.
articles.abstract: During the Celtic Tiger boom, snakes became a popular pet among the Irish nouveau riche. But after the bubble burst, many owners abandoned the pets they could no longer afford.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALLIVOR, Ireland — Legend has it that St. Patrick drove all the snakes out of Ireland. The economic crisis has brought some of them back.

articles.headline: Right to Lawyer Can Be Empty Promise for Poor
articles.snippet: Fifty years after the Supreme Court ruled in Gideon v. Wainwright, the promise of legal representation for all is not fully realized.
articles.abstract: Fifty years after the Supreme Court ruled in Gideon v. Wainwright, the promise of legal representation for all is not fully realized.
articles.lead_paragraph: ADEL, Ga. — Billy Jerome Presley spent 17 months in a Georgia jail because he did not have $2,700 for a child support payment. He had no prior jail record but also no lawyer. In Baltimore last fall, Carl Hymes, 21, was arrested on charges of shining a laser into the eyes of a police officer. Bail was set at $75,000. He had no arrest record but also no lawyer. In West Orange, N.J., last summer, Walter Bloss, 89, was served with an eviction notice from the rent-controlled apartment he had lived in for 43 years after a dispute with his landlord. He had gone to court without a lawyer.

articles.headline: JPMorgan’s Follies, for All to See
articles.snippet: The nation supposedly has new safeguards against another financial crisis. But a Senate report on JPMorgan Chase’s $6.2 billion trading loss offers cause for worry.
articles.abstract: The nation supposedly has new safeguards against another financial crisis. But a Senate report on JPMorgan Chase’s $6.2 billion trading loss offers cause for worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: BE afraid.

articles.headline: Coffee’s Economics, Rewritten by Farmers
articles.snippet: Some coffee farmers are taking control of more of the supply chain, roasting and marketing their own beans for greater profit.
articles.abstract: Some coffee farmers are taking control of more of the supply chain, roasting and marketing their own beans for greater profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN 2005, Kenneth Lander, a lawyer in Monroe, Ga., moved with his wife, stepdaughter and the youngest three of his seven children to a coffee farm in San Rafael de Abangares, Costa Rica. He always “had a heart,” he said, for Latin America, and after a vacation to the lush cloud forests near Monteverde in 2004, he was determined to return on a more permanent basis.

articles.headline: The Cossacks Are Back. May the Hills Tremble.
articles.snippet: Revered as fierce horsemen who once secured an empire’s frontier, Cossacks are gaining an increasing role in law enforcement in a newly conservative, nationalist Russia.
articles.abstract: Revered as fierce horsemen who once secured an empire’s frontier, Cossacks are gaining an increasing role in law enforcement in a newly conservative, nationalist Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: STAVROPOL, Russia — Outside this city’s police headquarters on a recent night, a priest in a purple velvet hat and gold stole moved from one man to the next, offering a cross to be kissed and drenching their faces with holy water from a long brush.

articles.headline: New Apartments Will Complicate Jerusalem Issue
articles.snippet: Israeli residences are being sandwiched into the fabric of Arab East Jerusalem, a construction many say undermines the idea that the area could serve as the capital of a Palestinian state.
articles.abstract: Israeli residences are being sandwiched into the fabric of Arab East Jerusalem, a construction many say undermines the idea that the area could serve as the capital of a Palestinian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Muslim call to prayer resounds through the traffic circle in the Palestinian enclave of Ras al-Amud, through the taxi stand where waiting drivers sip sweet coffee and the vegetable market where boys help their fathers after school. It can also be heard down the street in Maalot David, where a few Jewish families have quietly taken up residence in newly renovated apartments with prime views of Jerusalem’s Old City.

articles.headline: When Cold Cases Stay Cold
articles.snippet: A few years ago, the F.B.I. began reopening dozens of cold cases involving blacks killed in the South decades ago, but resolution has been elusive.
articles.abstract: A few years ago, the F.B.I. began reopening dozens of cold cases involving blacks killed in the South decades ago, but resolution has been elusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERRIDAY, La. — In the spring of 1965, the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington received a letter from Concordia Parish in northeastern Louisiana. Addressed to the bureau’s director, J. Edgar Hoover, the letter pleaded for justice in the killing of a well-respected black merchant.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry, Campbell Robertson and Robbie Brown

articles.headline:
Turmoil in Cyprus
Over a Bailout
Rattles Europe
articles.snippet: A decision to impose across-the-board losses on Cypriot depositors as part of a $13 billion bailout has fueled fears that bank runs there could spread to countries like Spain and Italy.
articles.abstract: A decision to impose across-the-board losses on Cypriot depositors as part of a $13 billion bailout has fueled fears that bank runs there could spread to countries like Spain and Italy.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Europe’s surprising decision early Saturday to force bank depositors in Cyprus to share in the cost of the latest euro zone bailout set off increasing outrage and turmoil in Cyprus on Sunday and fueled fears that the trouble will spread to countries like Spain and Italy.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Domestic Drones Stir Imaginations, and Concerns
articles.snippet: Companies, universities and lawmakers in the United States are preparing for a world in which remote-controlled planes will be ubiquitous in civilian air space.
articles.abstract: Companies, universities and lawmakers in the United States are preparing for a world in which remote-controlled planes will be ubiquitous in civilian air space.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — On the pilot’s computer screen, planted at ground level a few yards from the airport runway here, the data streaming across the display tracked an airplane at 1,300 feet above a small city on the coast, making perfect circles at 150 miles per hour.

articles.headline: Spreading Disruption, Shaking Up Cable TV
articles.snippet: Aereo, a start-up backed by Barry Diller that captures broadcast signals to be streamed online, is sowing chaos in the cable television business.
articles.abstract: Aereo, a start-up backed by Barry Diller that captures broadcast signals to be streamed online, is sowing chaos in the cable television business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The table in the conference room on the sixth floor of the IAC headquarters in Manhattan was a portrait of organization. In front of each of the 10 chairs was a leather case holding a fresh tablet of paper, with a sharpened pencil placed above it, just so. Everything in “the Helm,” as they call the room, was precise, orderly, logical. Just the way Barry Diller likes it.

articles.headline: Divided Views of SAC Capital Settlement
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. celebrated Friday’s settlement with SAC Capital Advisors, but both the fund and its rivals saw the $616 million fine as a good price for peace in the insider trading case.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. celebrated Friday’s settlement with SAC Capital Advisors, but both the fund and its rivals saw the $616 million fine as a good price for peace in the insider trading case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not many Wall Street executives, let alone hedge funds, could write a $616 million check and remain solvent.

articles.headline: Tax Credits or Spending? Labels, but in Congress, Fighting Words
articles.snippet: As lawmakers struggle to narrow the government’s deficit, every dollar taken from a grant program counts as a budget cut, while every dollar taken from a tax credit is instead a tax increase.
articles.abstract: As lawmakers struggle to narrow the government’s deficit, every dollar taken from a grant program counts as a budget cut, while every dollar taken from a tax credit is instead a tax increase.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a low-income neighborhood in Bozeman, Mont., taxpayers helped pay for the construction of a grocery store, Town and Country Foods. They are doing the same in New Orleans, with federal dollars helping to build new groceries, including a Whole Foods, in an area still suffering after Hurricane Katrina.

articles.headline: Terror Haven in Mali Feared After French Leave
articles.snippet: Western and African officials are increasingly concerned that the soldiers expected to continue the campaign against militants lack proper training and equipment.
articles.abstract: Western and African officials are increasingly concerned that the soldiers expected to continue the campaign against militants lack proper training and equipment.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEMA, Mauritania — With France planning to start withdrawing its troops from Mali next month, Western and African officials are increasingly concerned that the African soldiers who will be relied on to continue the campaign against militants linked to Al Qaeda there do not have the training or equipment for the job.

articles.headline: U.S. Looked at Wall Street Journal Over Claims of Bribery
articles.snippet: The investigation of The Wall Street Journal coincides with a broader search the government is conducting of News Corporation over a phone-hacking scandal in 2011.
articles.abstract: The investigation of The Wall Street Journal coincides with a broader search the government is conducting of News Corporation over a phone-hacking scandal in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States government’s inquiry into News Corporation broadened last year when the Justice Department investigated claims that employees in the China news bureau of The Wall Street Journal bribed local officials with gifts in exchange for information.

articles.headline: Hacker Case Leads to Calls for Better Law
articles.snippet: The indictment of Matthew Keys, 26, in relation to a 2010 incident of online vandalism has led to an outcry over sentencing in computer crimes.
articles.abstract: The indictment of Matthew Keys, 26, in relation to a 2010 incident of online vandalism has led to an outcry over sentencing in computer crimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Matthew Keys, the 26-year-old deputy social media editor at Reuters charged with assisting computer hackers, has emerged as the latest lightning rod in the continuing battle between proponents of Internet freedom and the Justice Department.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Starting a Papacy, Amid Echoes of a ‘Dirty War’
articles.snippet: The election of Francis is focusing scrutiny on his role at the Roman Catholic Church in Argentina, which was accused of complicity during a military junta’s violent reign.
articles.abstract: The election of Francis is focusing scrutiny on his role at the Roman Catholic Church in Argentina, which was accused of complicity during a military junta’s violent reign.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — One Argentine priest is on trial in Tucumán Province on charges of working closely with torturers in a secret jail during the so-called Dirty War, urging prisoners to hand over information. Another priest was accused of taking a newborn from his mother, one of the many baby thefts from female prisoners who were “disappeared” into a system of clandestine prisons.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and William Neuman

articles.headline: Trading Hearings Put Focus Back on JPMorgan’s Chief
articles.snippet: Some investors and board members have criticized Jamie Dimon as arrogant, but no serious threat to his power is expected.
articles.abstract: Some investors and board members have criticized Jamie Dimon as arrogant, but no serious threat to his power is expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the influential chief of JPMorgan Chase, watched from New York on Friday while in Washington his top lieutenants were questioned by a Senate panel over a multibillion-dollar trading loss.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: In Some States, Gun Rights Trump Orders of Protection
articles.snippet: Lobbyists and their allies are challenging states’ efforts to take guns from domestic violence offenders who have been served with civil protection orders.
articles.abstract: Lobbyists and their allies are challenging states’ efforts to take guns from domestic violence offenders who have been served with civil protection orders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early last year, after a series of frightening encounters with her former husband, Stephanie Holten went to court in Spokane, Wash., to obtain a temporary order for protection.
